questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the deep inguinal ring, which is formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text: A student had his jaw locked while yawning. Which of the following muscles is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
The muscle that is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid. 

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, the capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and the articular disc.

The action of lateral pterygoid muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw.

Related Pearl: Muscles of mastication

Muscles Origin Insertion Action
Lateral pterygoid

Upper head - Infratemporal surface, sphenoid bone

Lower head - Lateral pterygoid plate

Upper head - Pterygoid fovea 

Lower head - TMJ capsule and articular disc

Depresses mandible (with suprahyoid muscles)

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(Side to side) movements
Medial pterygoid

Superficial head - Maxilla

Deep head - Lateral pterygoid plate, Palatine bone

Angle of mandible

Ramus of mandible behind mandibular foramen

Elevates mandible  

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(side to side) movements
Temporalis

Temporal fossa

Temporal fascia

Ramus of mandible

Coronoid process

Elevates mandible

Side-to-side movements

Jaw retraction
Masseter Zygomatic arch Ramus of mandible

Elevates mandible

Jaw protrusion

questions.text: Identify the structure(s) in the following histological image.
questions.solution:
The above histology image shows the glomerulus.

Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium. Blood enters the tuft through an afferent arteriole and leaves it through an efferent arteriole. It is supported by the mesangium containing mesangial cells and a non-cellular mesangial matrix.

The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option A: Leydig cells, also known as interstitial cells of Leydig, are present in the interstitial connective between seminiferous tubules.

The testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between. Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells, which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells, which have a supportive function. 

The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells.

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. The islet cells are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

  • α or A cells - located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
  • β or B cells - located centrally and produce insulin 
  • δ or D cells - scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

The image given below shows the islets of Langerhans.

Option C: Hassall's corpuscles are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. Each corpuscle has a central core of degenerated epithelial cells and macrophages surrounded by concentrically arranged epithelial cells. The degenerated cells ultimately give pink staining hyaline mass. The function of the corpuscles of Hassall is still not known.

The image given below shows Hassall's corpuscle.

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.solution:
The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve (also know as common peroneal nerve)

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th and 5th lumbar and 1st and 2nd sacral ventral rami. It runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves.

  Superficial fibular nerve Deep fibular nerve
Motor innervation
  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius
Sensory innervation
  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital web-space

 
  • The first interdigital space
 

 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve) at the level of the neck of the fibula causes foot drop. Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot are lost, while the inversion and plantar flexion are usually preserved. Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot, including the first web space, is lost. The ankle reflex is usually preserved.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th aortic arch.

Usually, in term infants, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close results in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

PDA usually presents with a hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

In a majority of cases, PDA closes spontaneously. If spontaneous closure fails to occur, COX inhibitors like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be used. Surgical ligation is indicated in case of contraindications to medical management or failure of the same.

Other options

Option A: The 4th right aortic arch gives rise to the proximal part of the right subclavian artery. 

Option B: The 4th left aortic arch gives rise to the arch of the aorta. Defects involving the 4th left aortic arch could cause a variety of aortic arch anomalies, such as interruption of the aortic arch, but not PDA.

Option C: The 6th right aortic arch forms the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the allantois. Its distal portion forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum arising from anti-mesenteric border of ileum. It is a remnant of the proximal part of the vitelline duct, which is made up of pluripotent cell lining. Meckel's diverticulum may harbor abnormal tissues, containing embryonic remnants of other tissue types, mostly gastric mucosa.

Related Pearl: Remnants of Various Embryonic Parts of the Cardiovascular System

Embryonic part

Remnants

Ductus arteriosus

Ligamentum arteriosum

Umbilical artery

Proximal part: Superior vesical artery; Distal part: Medial umbilical ligament

Umbilical vein (left)

Ligamentum teres

Ductus venosus

Ligamentum venosum

Septum primum

Floor of fossa ovalis

Septum secundum

Lower free edge: Annulus ovalis

 curved upper Margin: limbus fossa ovalis

questions.text: A patient comes with abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension. Anastomosis between which of the following veins is seen?

choices.text: Left colic vein and middle colic veins
Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a patient with portal hypertension, anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.

In portal hypertension, increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in the dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses. 

Common sites of porto-systemic anastomoses and their clinical presentations are as follows:

Portal Systemic Clinical presentation
Left gastric vein Distal esophageal veins   Esophageal and gastric varices
Superior rectal vein Middle and inferior rectal veins Rectal varices
Persistent tributaries of the left branch of the portal vein in ligamentum teres Periumbilical branches of epigastric and intercostal veins Caput medusae
Right branch of portal vein Retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal, and phrenic veins Dilated retroperitoneal veins at risk during surgery or interventions
Omental and colonic veins Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures At risk during surgery

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling under the left ear lobule and complains of pain. Which of the following structures is the likely cause of the pain?

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The cause of the pain in this patient complaining of pain in the parotid region is likely to be the greater auricular nerve.

The greater auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the parotid gland and the ear lobule. Pain associated with swelling and inflammation in the parotid region could be transmitted through the greater auricular nerve. The parotid gland is covered by a parotid capsule that is derived from the investing layer of deep cervical fascia. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the pre­auricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

Other options:

Option A: The facial nerve is not the primary cause of pain in the parotid region due to swelling. The Hitzelberger sign(numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal), associated with facial nerve involvement, is seen in acoustic neuroma and is not the cause of pain in this scenario. 

Option D: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia is not the correct answer because the investing layer of deep cervical fascia itself does not transmit pain sensation. The investing layer of deep cervical fascia is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends to cover the parotid gland, forming the parotid capsule. While inflammation or swelling in the parotid gland can stretch the capsule and cause pain, the actual transmission of pain sensation is mediated by sensory nerves, such as the greater auricular nerve, which innervates the skin over the parotid gland and the ear lobule.

The greater auricular nerve (Option B) is a more appropriate answer in this context, as it is responsible for carrying the pain sensation from the area of swelling and inflammation in the parotid region.

Option C: The auriculotemporal nerve can cause referred pain due to caries tooth, ulcerative lesions of the oral cavity, temporomandibular joint disorders, and sphenopalatine neuralgia. However, it is not the primary cause of pain in the parotid region due to swelling.
